trial_identification.studytitle: Effect of exercise on mucus rheology and inspiratory/expiratory flow-volume relationships in people with Cystic Fibrosis
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Effect of cycle and treadmill endurance exercise on mucus rheology and inspiratory/expiratory flow-volume relationships in people with Cystic Fibrosis

interventions.interventions: Stable subjects will attend for testing on three days. First day, lung function and incremental cycle and treadmill tests to peak work capacity (randomised order) will be performed. On the second and third day, subjects will be randomised to perform 20 minutes of endurance exercise at 60% of peak work capacity on the cycle ergometer and the treadmill.
interventions.comparator: Control treatment was resting breathing for 20 minutes.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Mucus rheology. Samples collected are control-separated by 20 minutes.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: At pre-exercise, immediately post-exercise and 20 minutes post-exercise
Recorded throughout peak and endurance exercise tests

secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Immediately pre-intervention, immediately post-intervention, 20 minutes post-intervention

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Comparison of bike versus treadmill exercise capacity and effect on mucus rheology and flow-volume relationships.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Immediately pre-intervention, immediately post-intervention, 20 minutes post-intervention

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Comparison of peak and endurance exercise capacity.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Measurements taken each minute throughout the 20 minutes of endurance exercise and throughout the peak exercsise test.

eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Post lung transplant; infected with burkholderia cepacia complex; not clinically stable

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: Level 11, KGV Building Missenden Road Camperdown NSW 2050

fundingsource.fundingaddress: Research Administration Section National Health and Medical Research Council GPO Box 1412 Canberra ACT 2601

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The trial completed recruitment and data collection in 2007. Manuscript was published in Chest 2011, vol 139(4):870-877.
